awd_abstract_narration:
Morphogenesis, which is the process by which multi-cellular organisms acquire their "shape", is the ultimate challenge in the study of pattern formation. Morphogenesis executes a genetically encoded developmental program, and much of the prior work has been focused on the pattern of gene expression and the molecular signals that control it. Yet because morphogenesis involves spatial rearrangement and flow of cells, physical interaction of cells within tissue plays an important role. This project will address the role of mechanical stress in coordinating cellular and sub-cellular processes with the global organization and dynamics of tissues. The proposed work will involve intra- and extramural collaborations with experimental labs, funded by other sources. As a member of the Physics Department, the PI works with physics students encouraging and guiding their research on biology problems. As a member of the Kavli Institute for Theoretical Physics (KITP), the PI coordinates the Interdisciplinary Biology Initiative that runs programs designed to break barriers between disciplines. The PI also co-directs the Santa Barbara Advanced School of Quantitative Biology (SBASQB), which holds an annual advanced Summer Research Lab course on the UCSB campus and attracts young scientists with Physics and/or Biology backgrounds from the US and around the world. 

The PI will formulate and study a model of epithelial tissue mechanics in conjunction with quantitative analysis of experimental data for several prototypical steps of embryonic and larval development of a fruit fly. In contrast to the familiar viscoelasticity of passive materials, which are elastic at short times but flow relaxing the stress at long times, epithelial tissues can flow while remodeling at short times, yet at long times behave as a solid - an "Active Solid" supporting static external stress. This can be understood by invoking the activity of myosin motors and their ability to redistribute in a tension-dependent manner, which results in interesting and unusual response properties of this Active Solid state of living matter. The proposed work will apply these ideas to morphogenetic processes on large and small scales. On the large scale, the proposed work will develop a description of the global "Morphogenetic Flow" that rearranges tissues during gastrulation of Drosophila embryo, and aim to uncover the mechanism controlling the spatiotemporal pattern of myosin activation that defines the flow. On the smaller scale, it will model the mechanism of cell rearrangement during the larval stage of Drosophila eye development that leads to the formation of an ordered "ommatidial crystal" making up the fly's compound eye. The project will: 1) Develop the Active Solid Model (ASM) of epithelial tissue mechanics describing its fluid-like ability to rearrange that coexists with the ability to support steady external stress. Specifically: i) formulate a model of mechanical feedback on myosin recruitment, coupling myosin dynamics to the cytoskeletal stress and rate of strain; ii) derive a consistent continuum theory; iii) define quantitative predictions for the dynamic response to mechanical perturbations; iv) test and refine the model by comparing the predicted response with experimental data for Drosophila tissues. 2) Develop a quantitative description of global morphogenetic flow in Drosophila embryo in terms of myosin controlled continuous transformation of mechanical equilibria. The project will use the ASM framework to disentangle genetically controlled patterning of myosin activity from the effects of passive transport and mechanical feedback. Emerging hypotheses regarding relevant gene expression patterns will be tested by suitably designed experiments. 3) Develop a mechanical model to describe the observed rearrangement of cells leading to the ordered array of receptor-cells during Drosophila eye development. This project will build on the quantitative analysis of the new time-lapse imaging data, which documents the dynamics of "ommatidial crystal" formation with sub-cellular resolution.

por.por_cntn:
Morphogenesis is the process of biological shape formation, which unfolds as plants and animals develop from embryos into their adult forms. While developmental biology had historically focused on the genetic and biochemical aspects of organismal development, morphology and shape are intrinsically geometric and are molded by physical forces generated by cells as they grow, divide and rearrange themselves within tissues. The interplay between genes and geometry is mediated by cell and tissue mechanics, which necessitates the engagement of Physics in the study of Morphogenesis. It is increasingly realized that mechanical stress within tissues does not only deform cells but also has a regulatory role controlling cell behavior, such as cell growth and division, or remodeling of cellular cytoskeleton which is responsible for internal force generation, hence introducing a strong feedback into developmental process. Elucidating the interplay between genetic and mechanical regulation of development was the overarching goal of the project, which led to ten scientific publications on this subject including an influential review of the current knowledge and ideas on mechanical regulation of growth.

Work during the reporting period focused on i) establishing a mathematical and computational model of epithelial tissue mechanics and testing its predictions on experimental data; ii) developing methods for mechanical stress inference; iii) modeling specific morphogenetic processes. Among the highlights of the project was the formulation of the “Active Solid” model of epithelial tissue mechanics and experimental validation of one of the key predictions of the model: that myosin – the molecular motor responsible for cytoskeletal force generation – is dynamically recruited by the cell in response to the rate of strain within tissue. This effect is important as it shapes the mechanical response of tissues, while helping maintain their mechanical integrity. Another outcome of the project was the development of a novel non-invasive tool for mechanical stress inference based solely on imaging of cells in epithelial tissues. Stress inference is important because the field currently lacks reliable non-invasive experimental tools to measure stress distribution across tissues. The method uncovered the presence of static stress in the ectoderm of Drosophila embryo during the germband elongation step of its development. This is a surprising effect, given the dynamic nature of this process, yet it is entirely consistent with the “active solid” model of tissue mechanics. Other highlights of the work include a) the establishment of a stem-cell model of neural tube development, which enables a well-controlled in vitro study of tissue growth and differentiation process leading to a highly non-trivial 3D morphology; b) the first quantitative study of Drosophila midgut formation that revealed the role of patterned muscle contractions in determining the 3D shape of the gut. These studies involved integration of theory with experiment and were carried out in close collaboration with the laboratory of Prof. Streichan at UCSB.

Broader impacts of the project include the advancement of interdisciplinary training. First, the project provided an extensive multi-disciplinary research training for the participating graduate students and post-doctoral scholars. Second, the PI, as the founding director of the Santa Barbara Advanced School of Quantitative Biology co-organized  the 2019 summer research course “Form, Fate and Function” on the subject of Morphogenesis. The latter course for extramural students coming from across the nation and the world helped to broaden participation while also bringing together physicists and biologists, theorists and experimentalists, to help them learn the common scientific language that is necessary to work in multi-disciplinary teams. Last but not least, the PI had also organized and chaired the 27th Solvay Physics Conference “The Physics of Living Matter: Space, Time and Information,” helping to popularize this field of study as a sub-field of Physics. Solvay Conference Proceedings co-edited by the PI and published as a book by World Scientific provide a broad  survey of the subject with its challenges and ideas, serving as a guidebook for young scientists entering the field.
